reasoning: The critique targets a fairly central pillar of the essay’s conclusion—its Section 3 claim that (roughly) “most plausible moral views are fussy” and only a narrow slice are easygoing. If that generalization were substantially undermined, the overall ‘no easy eutopia’ case would be meaningfully weakened (though not fully, because Section 2’s “moral catastrophe is easy / value is fragile” argument could still support narrow-target conclusions independently). However, the critique is mostly schematic: it lists families of moral theories (threshold deontology, pluralism, virtue ethics, contractualism) and asserts they might make “mostly great” a large target, but it doesn’t show (i) that these views plausibly satisfy the paper’s formal setup (completeness/VNM-style representability), (ii) that they really yield broad near-best regions under the paper’s 0–1 normalization, or (iii) that they escape the paper’s specific drivers of fussiness (scale sensitivity, fat-tailed value-efficiency, bads-vs-goods aggregation). So it raises a live worry about model class misspecification but only modestly weakens the argument as presented. It is relevant to Forethought’s agenda because it bears directly on the Better Futures ‘no easy eutopia’ thesis (a Tier-2 commitment), but it’s not developed enough to strongly inform their active research directions.
title: "Bounded-unbounded taxonomy may overlook nuanced moral frameworks"
